moves.1. e4: Just a game i thought i would add to the annotations as an example of removing the defender.
moves.1... e5 2. Nf3 Nf6: Both knights threaten to capture central pawns.
moves.3. Bc4 Bd6: Development is a better option as you should never violate the golden rule " never move the same piece twice in the opening"
moves.4. d3: Trying to open up some space for my bishop to pin the knight.
moves.6... h6: Black trying to expell the bishop.  I dont want to run around so the exchange was accepted.  Also gets the black queen out early which is potentially good for white as you will see in a few more moves.
moves.7. Bxf6 Qxf6 8. Nc3 Nd4: Black trying to threaten Nxc2 or Nxf3 and if white Qxf3 then Black Qxf3 white will have to recapture with gxf3 leaving white king exposed.
moves.9. Nxd4: accept the exchange works out better for white.
moves.9... exd4 10. Nd5: Lets push the queen shall we.
moves.10... Qg6 11. Qf3: Looking to threaten the potentially weak f7 pawn and force black to castle kingside
moves.11... O-O: black takes the bait and the plan is in play.  Now to remove the defender of the e7 square and set up a fork.
moves.12. e5 Bxe5: Black grabs the bait twice in a row and its all over.
